results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Man and lions)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a man fights between two lions set against a black background. Made by Lawler, 161 Strand, London. ‘91’ written in pencil on wooden frame. Cream tape has been adhered to the edge of the sliding section.

results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a man fights between two lions set against a black background. results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows footage of Mt Buffalo and the Grampians, in Victoria, filmed in September 1944. Footage shows spectacular views from high up, waterfalls and rock formations and a peep at some buildings. Kenneth’s camera lingers over many of the waterfalls before moving onto a selection of flowers and bushes before ending the reel with pink tinged clouds. Title cards are used throughout the film.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:12:00 ‘Mt Buffalo September 1944’ low lying clouds and overlooking misty, foggy mountain scenery.
00:02:32:00 group of young women wearing jodhpurs which were worn by women at time for ourdoor activity.
00:03:50:00 hikers walking up a trial.

00:03:55:00 ‘Pulpit Rock’ sign followed by ‘Lake Catani’, a walking track, spillway, views across the lake and a group sitting on a short pier.

00:06:09:00 walkers waving at the camera from a high, jutting rock formation and viewing platform (possibly ‘the Monolith’).

00:10:08:00 filmmaker Kenneth walking along a track.

00:10:31:00 ‘View Point’ and hikers looking out over a dramatic view.

00:12:19:00 a group of hikers coming downwards and waving at the camera; sequence ends with pink tinged clouds.

00:12:42:00 ‘The Grampians September 1944’ appears followed by a distinctive tractor ploughing or planting in a farm paddock before moving to the scenery of the Grampians.

00:13:18:00 ‘Broken Falls’ sign, top of the waterfall and then full cascading waters across a wide section of rocks.

results.title: Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage interview
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, Warwick talks about his early days in Alice Springs and getting his start in radio before moving on to films. Warwick also discusses the reoccurring theme of the matriarch in his works and the freedom and joy he finds in installation art.

‘Mother Courage’ is a film and sculptural installation by the internationally acclaimed artist and filmmaker Warwick Thornton. Co-commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA (13) as part of the ACMI Commissions Series, ‘Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage’ was a free exhibition in Gallery Two at ACMI 2013. As one of the most exciting filmmakers working in Australia today, Warwick Thornton is best known for ‘Samson & Delilah’, winner of the 2009 Camera d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. His work, ‘Mother Courage’ (2012), is a dynamic, multi-screen art installation that features a dilapidated campervan as its centrepiece. Audiences will peer into the van’s grimy windows and through its rear doors, to view the provocative and poignant video contained within.

results.title: Back to being black
results.brief_description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.
results.description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.

results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly, David Batty, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Warlpiri Media and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: Contentment
results.creator_credit: Noel Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A shearer for thirty years, Noel Atkinson’s life was turned upside down when he discovered he had Parkinson’s Disease. His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Strong and Proud
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Darren Atkinson
results.brief_description: Darren grew up on Cummeragunja Mission and in this digital story he talks about his grandfather’s life, the Koori community and the handing down of Indigenous traditions and culture from one generation to the next.
